body:
Hi,

Just to let you know that I am still waiting for the solution. Thank you very much.

Hi,
sorry for the long wait. I'm currently looking into it. The distances should be easy to fix, the angles proof to be a little trickier.

Another thing I noticed is that when I use the Behler representation, with radial function only, I get nan for loss for all the time. It doesn't matter how I set the learning rate. 
```
import schnetpack.output_modules
from schnetpack.data import AtomsData
import pickle
import json
import torch
import torch.nn.functional as F
from torch.optim import Adam

import schnetpack as spk
import schnetpack.atomistic as atm
import schnetpack.representation as rep
from schnetpack.datasets import *
from schnetpack.metrics import MeanSquaredError
from schnetpack.environment import AseEnvironmentProvider

config = {'Database':{'Name': 'BPNN_original_300_diag',
                      'datafile': './db/master-jb.db',
                      'train_size': 300,
                      'val_size': 100,
                      'batch_size': 5},
          'Fingerprints':{'n_radial': 4,
                          'n_angular': 0,
                          'cutoff_radius': 6,
                          'mode': 'Behler'},
          'Model':{'Type': 'BPNN',
                   'n_layers': 2,
                   'n_hidden': 100,
                   'lr': 1e-4,
                   'E_coef': 1,
                   'F_coef': 1,
                   'val_interval': 1,
                   'n_epochs': 1000}}


Name = config['Database']['Name']
datafile = config['Database']['datafile']
train_size = config['Database']['train_size']
val_size = config['Database']['val_size']
batch_size = config['Database']['batch_size']
n_radial = config['Fingerprints']['n_radial']
n_angular = config['Fingerprints']['n_angular']
cutoff_radius = config['Fingerprints']['cutoff_radius']
mode = config['Fingerprints']['mode']
n_layers = config['Model']['n_layers']
n_hidden = config['Model']['n_hidden']
lr = config['Model']['lr']
E_coef = config['Model']['E_coef']
F_coef = config['Model']['F_coef']
val_interval = config['Model']['val_interval']
n_epochs = config['Model']['n_epochs']



if not os.path.exists(Name):
    os.makedirs(Name)

config_name = f'./{Name}/config.json'
with open(config_name,'w') as f:
    json = json.dump(config,f)

#config_file = open(config_name,'w')
#config_file.write(json)
#config_file.close()

data = AtomsData(datafile, required_properties=['energy','forces','stress'],collect_triples=True,environment_provider = AseEnvironmentProvider(cutoff_radius))


train, val, test = data.create_splits(train_size, val_size)
train_loader = spk.data.AtomsLoader(train, batch_size=batch_size, num_workers=0)
val_loader = spk.data.AtomsLoader(val)
test_loader = spk.data.AtomsLoader(test)
loader = [train_loader, val_loader, test_loader]
pickle.dump(loader, open('./'+Name+'/loader.sav','wb'))


reps = rep.BehlerSFBlock(n_radial=n_radial, n_angular=n_angular, elements=frozenset([46,79]), cutoff_radius=cutoff_radius, mode = mode)
reps = rep.StandardizeSF(reps, train_loader)
mean, stddev = train_loader.get_statistics('energy', True)


# Should be noticed that I add a "negative_dr" argument here. I did this to make sure the force is the negative gradient. I also modified the code in output_module to accommodate that. 
output = schnetpack.output_modules.ElementalAtomwise(n_in=reps.n_symfuncs,n_layers=n_layers,n_hidden=n_hidden, elements=frozenset([46,79]),property='energy',derivative='forces',negative_dr=True,create_graph=True,mean=mean['energy'],stddev=stddev['energy'])
model = atm.AtomisticModel(reps, output,elements=frozenset([46,79]))

trainable_params = filter(lambda p: p.requires_grad, model.parameters())

metric_E = [MeanSquaredError(target = 'energy',model_output='energy'),MeanSquaredError(target = 'forces',model_output='forces')]
hook_E = spk.train.CSVHook("./"+Name, metric_E)

opt = Adam(trainable_params, lr=lr)

loss = lambda b, p: E_coef*F.mse_loss(p["energy"], b['energy'])+F_coef*F.mse_loss(p["forces"], b['forces'])
trainer = spk.train.Trainer(Name+"/", model, loss,
                            opt, train_loader, val_loader,hooks = [hook_E], validation_interval = val_interval)

# start training
trainer.train(torch.device("cpu"),n_epochs = n_epochs)
```
If you don't notice that problem, it will be great if you could show me the set up for running the code. Thank you very much!
Thanks for working on this problem @mgastegger -- our group is also very interested in seeing this fixed.

Just an update, distances are running properly, at least for energies. I will check the forces next, to see whether they are the source of the NaNs. I'm also working on the angular symmetry functions.

Hi, 

I believe the NaN problem is not in the forces. They were probably from the fingerprints. I wrote radial fingerprint function. While it is kind of slow, it does not give me the NaN problem. Also, I am wondering where I can get the the updated distances. It will be great to have a model where the radial symmetry could work, even if the angular symmetry function is not working yet. Thanks!

Thanks for the information.
Unfortunately, I was sidetracked by a few submission deadlines until now.
I will push a version with the distances fixed on Monday.
Sounds good. Thanks for working on it!

issue.title: Periodic boundary conditions for radial SFs

repository.name: schnetpack
repository.description: SchNetPack - Deep Neural Networks for Atomistic Systems

issue.body:
Partial fix for SFs with periodic boundary conditions in issue #104.
Angular functions currently in work.

body:
Radial SFs should work with PBC now. The angular ones will take more time.

@lmj1029123: Unfortunately, I was not able to reproduce the NaN issue using the materials project data and your script. Does the problem arise immediately, or only after a time? You could also disabling the StandardizeSF layer to see, whether this is the issue.

> Radial SFs should work with PBC now. The angular ones will take more time.
> 
> @lmj1029123: Unfortunately, I was not able to reproduce the NaN issue using the materials project data and your script. Does the problem arise immediately, or only after a time? You could also disabling the StandardizeSF layer to see, whether this is the issue.

The problem arise immediately. However, the NaN issue actually goes away with PBC fix. Thanks!
Great to hear, I'll keep you updated on the angular functions.

Hi,

I think I have a fix for the angular symmetry functions and I made a pull request for it. It seems that it is really expensive as it looks at N_atoms^2 neighbor pairs. I am not sure whether my implementation is compatible with GPU, Also, I am wondering whether there is tutorial of how to use GPU for schnetpack? Thanks!

Thank you very much, that was a huge help!
I went through the code and ran a few tests. It works on GPU and CPU and appears to be stable for gradients. The scaling of the angular functions is always a problem. Avoiding this is one of the advantages of SchNet. 

For running on GPU it should be enough to change your example script to contain:
`device = torch.device('cuda')`
`model = atm.AtomisticModel(reps, output,elements=frozenset([46,79])).to(device)`

Sorry again for the delay, we were quire busy but now things should be back to normal.
